Activate your account (no cost to the first 1,000 caregivers) and learn more about becoming a paid Peer Listener through Kindly Humans platform.Learn MoreGet StartedHave you ever wondered how you can get paid to be a family caregiver? If so, you are not alone! This is one of the most frequently asked questions. Unfortunately, we cannot provide you with a one-size-fits-all answer.You have the best chance of being paid to be a family caregiver if you care for a veteran. It also applies if your loved one is eligible for Medicaid, but other possibilities exist. These include long-term care policies, tax credits, and reimbursements for family caregiving expenses.Getting paid for caring for a loved one with VA benefitsIf your loved one is a veteran of the U.S. military, there are four plans for which they might qualify. VA benefits change periodically, so checking for updates is always a good idea. It is important to stay informed about the latest VA benefits for caregivers.Veteran-Directed Careis a program through the Department of Veterans Affairs for veterans who are enrolled in a Veterans Health Administration healthcare system and need nursing care but want to live at home. Participants are given a monthly budget and can choose the goods and services most helpful to them. This includes a caregiver to assist them with activities of daily living tailored to their specific needs.Aid and Attendance(A&A) benefits support veterans who qualify for a VA pension, having served on active duty for at least 90 days during a time of war and received an honorable discharge. Veterans must meet one of these criteria: require assistance with daily activities, be confined to bed due to a disability, have minimal eyesight, or live in a nursing home due to a physical or mental incapacity.Veteran Caregiver Benefits: Housebound & Assistance ProgramsHousebound benefitsare for veterans receiving a military pension who are housebound due to a permanent disability. Please note that under this program, adult children and other relatives can become paid caregivers for family members. However, this program does not allow spouses to be paid caregivers for their family members. The application is the same as for A&A benefitsbut you cannot receive both simultaneously.TheProgram of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregiversis for caregivers of veterans who need help with activities of daily living due to an injury or illness sustained in the line of duty on or before May 7, 1975, or on or after September 11, 2001. To be eligible, veterans must meet certain disability and need criteria. Stipends are based on the federal pay rate for where the veteran lives. Under this program, the caregiver must be 18 years or older and can be a spouse.For more information on caregiver benefits for veterans, visit theVA Caregiver Support pageor call its hotline at 855-260-3274.Getting paid to be a family caregiver through MedicaidMedicaid is a federally funded state program that assists with healthcare costs for people with limited income. It covers low-income adults, older adults, and individuals with significant disabilities across the United States. This may be a good time to mention that Medicaid and Medicare are different programs.To be eligible for Medicaid, your loved one must meet one of the following criteria:Be considered low-income according to the guidelines in the state where they have established residence. To qualify, one must make around 138% of the poverty limit or lower.Be considered medically needymeaning that their health needs are intensive and may require overwhelming expense.Medicaid in some states allows older adults to choose and pay their caregivers, including adult children or spouses. This flexibility varies by state, offering options for individuals needing caregiving support through Medicaid plans.Home and community-based waivershelp older adults who would rather receive in-home care. Qualifications vary by state; generally, older adults must require care provided by skilled nursing or assisted living facilities. To qualify, there must be a care plan, and in-home care costs cannot exceed residential care costs.Self-Directed Care Programs for Seniors and Medicaid OptionsSelf-directed person assistant servicesallow seniors to hire caregiversusually family members or close friends. Under the program, the participant must develop a care plan with the caregiver and establish a backup plan if the selected caregiver can no longer continue in their caregiver role.Community First Choiceis similar to the other Medicaid programs. Under the plan, seniors can manage their own careincluding paying family or friends for their caregiving services. This plan was established under the Affordable Care Act and is available in nine states: AK, CA, CT, MD, MT, NY, OR, TX, and WA.For more information on Medicaid, go to:https://www.medicaid.gov/.Getting paid for caregiving for a parent through tax credits and reimbursementsThere are several tax credits and reimbursements available for caregivers. If your parents gross annual incomenot including society securityis less than $4,300 and you cover more than half the support cost, claiming them as a dependent may be possible. Even if these criteria dont apply, deducting the majority of care expenses from your taxes might be possible. It would be best if you were sure to consult an accountant or tax attorney. The regulations vary by state, and some state-funded caregiver payment programs do not allow family members to claim their elderly loved ones as dependents on their taxes. These options may not be financially beneficial for you in the long run.Getting paid for caregiving by your loved oneOne possible way for your loved one to pay you for caregiving is if they have long-term care insurance. Policies vary by company, but many long-term care policies allow payment for in-home caregiving. The insurance company can tell you if a family member can provide this care.Another option is if your loved one is of sound mind and financially capable, they can pay you directly. Consider drafting a personal care contract outlining compensation and caregiving services. You may want to include other immediate family members in the discussion to avoid surprises or misunderstandings later.You should also consult an elder care attorney to ensure the contract complies with tax laws. Any compensation received is considered income and should be reported on your taxes. Suppose your loved one is currently on Medicaid or may be in the future. In that case, you want to ensure that any payments made to you dont violate their eligibility requirements or Medicaid regulations. Other interested parties, such as siblings, should also approve the agreement. This could help avoid any hurt feelings or disagreements regarding issues of inheritance.Additional Financial & Legal ToolsHow to Become a Paid Family CaregiverRead MoreMedicare Help Senior Patients and Caregivers for DecadesRead MoreWhy Medicare Coverage is Critical to CaregiversRead MoreFinancial Help for Caregivers: SilverBills Partnership and NIH StudyRead More12NextLoad More PostsHelp SupportCaregiversAcross the Nation1150 Connecticut Ave, NW, Suite 501, Washington, DCinfo@caregiveraction.orgClick to Call Caregiver Help Desk: (855) 227-3640Quick LinksCaregiver Help DeskLend Your VoiceCorporate PartnersSpeaker RequestsPublic PolicydonateCelebrate the passion and devotion of caregivers!Donate TodaynewsletterSign up for caregiving insights from us:Name(Required)FirstLastEmail(Required)Tell us about yourself(Required)Tell us about yourselfFamily CaregiverFormer CaregiverOtherHelp Support Caregivers Across the NationQuick LinksCaregiver Help DeskLend Your VoiceCorporate PartnersSpeaker RequestsPublic Policy1150 Connecticut Ave, NW, Suite 501, Washington, DCinfo@caregiveraction.orgHelp Desk: (855) 227-3640Copyright 2025, National Family Caregivers Association DBA Caregiver Action Network. However, with the right preparation, its possible to ease the challenges youll face along the way.Understanding the basics of caregiving, from learning about your loved ones condition to organizing care routines and embracing self-care, will help ensure a smoother journey. This guide provides essential caregiving tips fornew caregiversand highlights keyfamily caregiver resourcesthat can support you throughout the process.Educating YourselfOne of the first and most important steps fornew caregiversis learning as much as possible about your loved ones disease or condition. This knowledge will make caregiving less daunting and allow you to anticipate changes and challenges. There are numerous online resources about disease progression, treatment options, and management strategies, which can help you feel more prepared. Be sure to ask your loved ones healthcare provider for advice, as they may have insights and recommendations specific to your situation.Understanding your loved ones condition can also improve your ability to offer compassionate care. Knowing what to expect helps reduce anxiety and uncertainty for both of you. For more resources on common conditions and caregiving strategies, explore theFamily Caregiver Toolboxon our website.Managing Your EmotionsCaring for a loved one can stir a range of emotions, from frustration and anxiety to moments of joy.Managing emotions as a caregiveris key to maintaining your own well-being and fostering a positive environment. One effective strategy is to focus on being present with your loved one, even when things feel beyond your control. Engaging in activities that you both enjoy can help strengthen your bond and create more peaceful moments during stressful times.Some great activities for caregivers and their loved ones include cooking, gardening, crafting, playing games, reading, or light exercise. These shared experiences can bring you closer and help reduce emotional strain.Staying OrganizedBeing organized is essential for successful caregiving. Keeping a detailed file of medical records, medications, and healthcare appointments will allow you to manage the caregiving process more effectively. A system of organization not only helps reduce stress but also strengthens trust between you, your loved one, and their healthcare providers.Consider establishing a daily routine to create a sense of stability. Having a predictable schedule can help reduce anxiety for your loved one, making their environment feel more secure. Maintaining communication with your loved one is also key to building trust.Keeping a journal is an excellent way to stay organized and manage your emotions. You can track everything from doctors visits to caregiving expenses. Whether you prefer traditional notebooks or digital journals, there are many resources available, such as caregiver-specific journals onAmazonorEtsy. Journals can be a powerful tool to manage both practical tasks and your mental well-being.Self-Care for CaregiversOne of the most important caregiving tips is to take care of yourself. Neglecting your own well-being can lead tocaregiving burnout. To stay healthy, make self-care a priority by scheduling time for yourself each day. Simple actions such as eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, and getting enough sleep can go a long way toward preventing burnout.Setting boundaries is another important part of self-care. Its okay to say no when you need time to rest or recharge. For additional support on avoiding caregiver burnout, check out ourself-care tipsand our blog on how tocope with caregiver stress.Utilizing Technology and ResourcesIn todays world, technology can be a valuable tool fornew caregivers. There are severalcaregiver support appsavailable to help manage caregiving tasks more effectively. One such app isCaring Village, which helps caregivers create to-do lists, manage medications, and store important documents in one convenient place. This app is available for both Android and iPhone users.Another helpful tool isLotsa Helping Hands, which works like a social media platform for caregivers. This app allows you to create centralized calendars for your care team, enabling family members or friends to assist with caregiving tasks. With these tools, managing caregiving tasks becomes more streamlined and less overwhelming.Asking for HelpIts important to remember that you dont have to do this alone. Reaching out for support when needed can make a huge difference in your caregiving experience. TheCaregiver Action Networks Caregiver Help Deskoffers free support for family caregivers. You can contact them by phone, email, or live chat to get expert advice.If youre looking for more assistance, our Agencies and Organizations resource list below provides a comprehensive list of trusted caregiving organizations that offer support to new caregivers. Additionally, dont hesitate to turn to your personal support network of family and friends when caregiving challenges arise.For more information and resources tailored specifically to new caregivers, check out ourI Just Realized Im a Family Caregiverpage.
